question: Neither did I. I was a cynic, just like you. Then I saw a girl step into a great fire with three stone eggs. When the fire burned out I thought I’d find her blackened bones. Instead I found her. Daenerys. Alive and unhurt. Holding her baby dragons. Have you ever heard baby dragons singing?
answer: No.

question: It's hard to be a cynic after that.
answer: Doesn’t mean she’s going to be a great queen.

question: No it doesn’t.
answer: The Targaryens are famously insane. What if she conquers the world? Then what? 1,000 years of peace and prosperity?

question: First we have to conquer the world.
answer: We? Alright, let’s assume your dreams come true. She’s ecstatic when you bring her this enemy dwarf. She hacks off my head and restores your position. You command her army, sail to Westeros, defeat all your enemies, then watch as she climbs those steps and sits on the Iron Throne. Hurrah, long live the Queen. Then what?

question: Then she rules.
answer: So a woman who has not spent a single day of her adult life in Westeros becomes the ruler of Westeros? That’s justice?

question: She is the rightful heir.
answer: Why, because her father who burned living men for amusement was the king?

question: Shh! It’s a slave ship
answer: Why is it anchored?

question: It will be a dwarf-sized cock.
answer: Guess again.

question: We’re bound to Volantis, not Slaver’s Bay. Besides, she reopened the fighting pits. I never heard of free men fighting in the pits.
answer: The fighting puts in Mereen! You’re in luck then, you’re about to be rich. You are looking at one of the great warriors in the seven kingdoms.

question: Him? He’s got to be 60 years old.
answer: Sure, he’s a bit long in the tooth, a bit withered, been in the sun too long. We can all see that. But he is a veteran of 100 battles. They wrote songs about him!

question: Why?
answer: We’re a team. I’m a great fighter, too.

question: Yes.
answer: My Lord, if I may. I’ve heard Mereen’s become a free city. You might run into trouble if you try to fight slaves in the fighting pits. Now if you were to fight free men who were paid a wage…

question: Who are you?
answer: I am the gift. It’s a pleasure to meet you, Your Grace. My name is Tyrion Lannister.

question: You will not speak. How do I know you are who you say you are?
answer: If only I were otherwise.

question: If you are Tyrion Lannister why shouldn’t I kill you? To pay your family back for what it did to mine
answer: You want revenge against the Lannisters? I killed my mother Joanna Lannister the day I was born. I killed my father Tywin Lannister with a bow to the heart. I am the greatest Lannister killer of our time.

question: So I should welcome you into my service because you murdered members of your own family?
answer: Into your service? Your Grace we have only just met. It’s too soon to know if you deserve my service.

question: If you’d rather return to the fighting pits just say the word.
answer: When I was a young man I heard a story about a baby born during the worst storm in living memory. She had no wealth, no lands, no army, only a name and a handful of supporters, most of whom probably thought they could use that name to benefit themselves. They kept her alive, moving her from place to place, often hours ahead of the men who had been sent to kill her. She was eventually sold off to some warlord on the edge of the world and that appeared to be that. And then a few years later the most well informed person I knew told me that this girl without wealth, lands, or armies had somehow acquired all 3 in a very short span of time, along with three dragons. He thought she was our best, last chance to build a better world. I thought you were worth meeting at the very least.

question: And why are you worth meeting? Why should I spend my time listening to you?
answer: Because you can not build a better world on your own. You have no one at your side who understands that land you want to rule. The strengths and the weaknesses of the houses that will either support or oppose you.

question: I have a very large army and very large dragons.
answer: Killing and politics aren’t always the same thing. When I served as Hand of the King I did quite well with the latter considering the king in question preferred torturing animals to leading his people. I could do an even better job advising a ruler worth the name.

question: So you want to advise me. Very well. (looks to Jorah) What would you have me do with him? I swore I would kill him if he ever returned.
answer: I know.

question: Why should the people trust a queen who can’t keep her promises?
answer: Whomever Ser Jorah was when he started informing on you, he is no longer that man. I can’t remember seeing the same man as devoted to anything as he is to serving you. He claims he would kill for you and die for you, and nothing I have witnessed gives me reason to doubt him. And yet he did betray you.

question: Yes, many opportunities.
answer: And did he?

question: No. Not until forced to do so.
answer: He worships you. He is in love with you, I think. But he did not trust you with the truth - an unpleasant truth, to be sure - but one of great significance to you. He did not trust that you would be wise enough to forgive him.

question: So I should kill him?
answer: A ruler who kills those that are devoted to her is not a ruler that inspires devotion. And you’re going to need to inspire devotion, and lots of it, if you’re ever going to rule across the Narrow Sea. But you cannot have him by your side when you do.

question: So have you decided yet? Whether I’m worthy of your service?
answer: Have you decided yet whether you’re going to have me killed?

question: It’s probably my safest option.
answer: I can see why you would think so. It’s what your father would have done.

question: And what would your father do?
answer: My father? Who publicly sentenced me to death? I’d say his thoughts on having me killed were abundantly clear.

question: Is that why you killed him?
answer: Some day if you decide not to execute me, I’ll tell you all about why I killed my father. And on that day, should it ever come, we’ll need more wine than this.

question: I know what my father was. What he did. I know the Mad King earned his name.
answer: So here we sit, two terrible children of two terrible fathers.

question: I’m terrible?
answer: I’ve heard stories.

question: Why did you travel to the other side of the world to meet someone terrible?
answer: To see if you were the right kind of terrible.

question: Which kind is that?
answer: The kind that prevents your people from being even more so.

question: I did reopen the fighting pits. Under my rule murder will once again become entertainment.
answer: Yes, that was wise. And you agreed to marry someone you loathed for the greater good. Very impressive. My own sister married someone she loathed as well, though not by choice and certainly not for the greater good, Gods forbid. She ended up having him killed.

question: Perhaps it won’t come to that.
answer: It’s not impossible that Varys was right about you after all.

question: Varys? King Robert’s spy master?
answer: Yes. He was the one who convinced me to come find you. He was my travelling companion before Ser Jorah seized that role for himself.

question: Jorah sent my secrets to Varys. For 20 years the spider oversaw the campaign to find and kill me.
answer: He did what he had to do to survive. He did a lot of other things that he didn’t have to do. I suspect he’s the main reason you weren’t slaughtered in your crib.

question: But you trust him?
answer: Yes, oddly. He might be the only person in the world that I trust. Besides my brother.

question: The brother who killed my father.
answer: That’s the one.

question: Perhaps I will have you killed after all.
answer: Your queenly prerogative. I had given up on life until Varys convinced me you might be worth living for. You chop off my head? Well, my final days were interesting.

question: I’m not going to kill you.
answer: No? Banish me?

question: No.
answer: So if I’m not going to be murdered, and I’m not going to be banished...

question: You’re going to advise me. (takes his wine cup) While you can still speak in complete sentences.
answer: Advise you on what?

question: How to get what I want.
answer: The Iron Throne. Perhaps you should try wanting something else.

question: If I want jokes I’ll get myself a proper fool.
answer: I’m not entirely joking. There’s more to the world than Westeros after all. How many hundreds of thousands of lives have you changed for the better here? Perhaps this is where you belong. Where you can do the most good.

question: I fought so that no child born into Slaver’s Bay would ever know what it was like to be bought or sold. I will continue that fight here and beyond. But this is not my home.
answer: And when you get back to your home, who supports you?

question: The common people.
answer: Let’s be generous and assume that’s going to happen. Here in Slaver’s Bay you had the support of the common people and only the common people. What was that like, ruling without the rich? House Targaryen is gone, not a single person who shares your blood is alive to support you. The Starks are gone as well, our two terrible fathers saw to that. The remaining Lannisters won’t back you, not ever. Stannis Baratheon won’t back you either, his entire claim to the Throne depends on the illegitimacy of yours. That leaves the Tyrells. Not impossible, but not enough.

question: Lannister, Targaryen, Baratheon, Stark, Tyrell. They’re all just spokes on a wheel. This one's on top, then that ones on top and on and on it spins, crushing the people on the ground.
answer: It’s a beautiful dream. Stopping the wheel. You’re not the first person to have dreamt it.

question: That one, the smaller man, no question, that’s where you should put your money.
answer: The smaller man it is.

question: You don’t approve?
answer: There’s always been more than enough death in the world for my taste. I can do without it in my leisure time.

question: Fair enough, yet -- it’s an unpleasant question -- but what great thing has ever been accomplished without killing or cruelty?
answer: It’s easy to confuse what is with what ought to be. Especially when what is has worked in your favor.

question: That is a vital part of the great city of Meereen. Which has existed long before you arrived and will remain standing long after we have returned to the dirt.
answer: My father would have liked you.

question: So your reasons are true, and theirs are false. They don’t know their own minds, but you do.
answer: Well said, you’re an eloquent man. Doesn’t mean you’re wrong. In my experience, eloquent men are right every bit as often as imbeciles.

question: She cannot.
answer: You can!

question: You walk like a rich person.
answer: You’ve spent a lot of time studying the way rich people walk?

question: You walk as though the paving stones were your personal property. I used to steal from people like you when I was a boy.
answer: It’s a good thing you’re not a boy anymore...because you have no cock.

question: Mhysa means mother in Valyrian.
answer: I know what mhysa means.

question: Who wrote it?
answer: Hard to know. Our queen is not as popular in Meereen as she used to be.

question: The Sons of the Harpy?
answer: Very possibly. Daenerys Targaryen took away their most valuable property, told them human beings weren’t even property to begin with. You can see why they’re unhappy. Of course, it could also be the freed men.

question: The Lord of Light sent the Mother of Dragons to you, and those who love the darkness chased her away.
answer: Many of the former slaves feel that Daenerys has abandoned them.

question: How will you respond? Will you wring your hands, while you wait for the Mother of Dragons to return? Or will you you take up her flames yourselves? Will you fight for your own salvation, now that Queen Daenerys is not here to fight for you?
answer: It’s a problem.

question: The Sons of the Harpy planned their attack in the fighting pits very carefully, which means they take orders from someone.
answer: And have you started looking for that someone?

question: No tears.
answer: I know it was hard for you. You turned away a man who truly loves you because he would have been a liability in the Seven Kingdoms. That’s the kind of self-sacrifice that makes for a good ruler, if it’s any consolation.

question: It’s not.
answer: No, I suppose not. I’m terrible at consoling.

question: Yes, you really are.
answer: All right, how about the fact that this is actually happening? You have your armies, you have your ships, you have your dragons. Everything you’ve ever wanted since you were old enough to want anything. It’s all yours for the taking. Are you afraid?

question: Do you know what frightens me? I said farewell to a man who loves me. A man I thought I cared for. And I felt nothing. Just impatient to get on with it.
answer: He wasn’t the first to love you and he won’t be the last.

question: It’s your counsel I need.
answer: It’s yours. Now and always.

question: I do not make dwarf jokes.
answer: You think them.

question: We are searching for the men who burned the ships, but nobody saw anything.
answer: Surely there’s some good news lurking somewhere.

question: Astapor and Yunkai have stopped asking us for aid.
answer: Perhaps they can tell us their secret.

question: The Masters have retaken both cities. Outside of Meereen, the whole of Slaver’s Bay has returned to the slavers.
answer: What about the dragons? We have two of them here beneath the pyramid.

question: They are not eating. They haven’t touched any food since Queen Daenerys left.
answer: Daenerys is the dragon queen. Can’t very well let the dragons starve, that’s obvious.

question: If a dragon does not want to eat, how do you force him to eat?
answer: Dragons do not do well in captivity.

question: How do you know this?
answer: That’s what I do. I drink and I know things.

question: Many times.
answer: And did they ever harm you?

question: Never.
answer: Dragons are intelligent. More intelligent than men according to some maesters. They have affection for their friends and fury for their enemies. I am their friend.

question: Do they know that?
answer: They will. It’s time they had their supper.

question: Patrol. When I am going on patrol with the Unsullied. What we see on patrol. Who we captured on patrol.
answer: That’s good. That’s very good.

question: Who said this?
answer: Me. Just now. All right, no conversations. Let’s play a game.

question: My master Kraznys would sometimes make us play games.
answer: There, that’s a start.

question: Only the girls.
answer: Oh no, no, no. Not that, of course not that. Innocent games, fun games, drinking games.

question: We do not drink.
answer: Until you do.

question: The good masters of Astapor. And the wise masters of Yunkai. With help from their friends in Volantis.
answer: You see? You don’t even have to worry about the local rebellion. We only have to worry about the three rich foreign cities paying for it.

question: We conquered Asatapor and Yunkai once. We will do it again and execute the Masters.
answer: If the Unsullied march off to reconquer Asatapor and Yunkai, who remain to defend the free people of Meereen?

question: So we will fight them?
answer: Possibly.

question: Possibly?
answer: It’s a conversation.

question: You invite the enemy into our city?
answer: I did. As a clever man once told me, “We make peace with our enemies, not our friends.”

question: I don’t make peace with the queen’s enemies. I kill the queen’s enemies.
answer: Yes, that’s the military approach. And how has that worked here in Meereen? I represent the diplomatic approach.

question: I bought this dwarf for a single gold honor. And somehow you’ve risen to the top of the Great Pyramid of Meereen. It’s most impressive.
answer: And now you speak for the Good Masters of Astapor.Here’s to reversals of fortune.

question: We came here to meet the queen and instead we’re greeted by a dwarf and a eunuch.
answer: Let’s make this simple, shall we? Tell me what you want.

question: We want you to leave Slaver’s Bay. Take your dragons and your mercenaries and go.
answer: Queen Daenerys won’t stay in Meereen forever. Her path takes her westward.

question: You think you’re a free man now? You still follow orders. Just because your master has silver hair and tits doesn’t mean she’s not a master.
answer: Friends, friends, friends, please.

question: Slavery is the way of our world.
answer: You don’t need slaves to make money. There haven’t been slaves in Westeros for hundreds of years and I grew up richer than any of you. But our queen recognizes that she erred by abolishing slavery without providing a new system to replace it. So here is the queen’s proposal. Slavery will never return to Meereen but she will give the other cities of Slaver’s Bay time to adjust to the new order.

question: What does that mean?
answer: Instead of abolishing slavery overnight, we will give you seven years to end the practice.

question: We do not support the Sons of the Harpy.
answer: Fine, fine, but you will cut it off all the same. I do hope you accept, my friends. You will not receive a better offer.

question: We speak the Common Tongue.
answer: Excellent.

question: You met with the slavers today.
answer: I did.

question: Our brothers and sister died fighting these scum. Now you invite them to our city and drink wine with them.
answer: I imagine this room was built so the rulers could intimidate the ruled.

question: You are a stranger here. So why do you represent Meereen in these talks with our enemies?
answer: Because our queen chose me as her advisor. Until she returns from her travels --

question: When does she return?
answer: Soon. You have my word.

question: We don’t know you. We don’t trust you. We know Torgo Nudho. We fight with him against the Masters. We trust him.
answer: And that is exactly why Grey Worm took part in these negotiations. As commander of the Unsullied, he knows hot to defeat the slavers and he knows when it is time to make peace.

question: You have made peace with the slavers?
answer: We offered terms.

question: Do not use me for your lies.
answer: Those men respect you.

question: They respect me because they know who I am. They know I am loyal.
answer: As do I.

question: I am loyal to my queen, not you. If you betray her work, you are my enemy.
answer: I am not betraying her work. I am trying to save her city.

question: You promised the slavers they could keep slavery.
answer: For a short time.

question: Seven years is not a short time for a slave.
answer: You’re right. Slavery is a horror that should be ended at once. War is a horror that should be ended at once. I can’t do both today.

question: You are wrong to trust these men.
answer: I don’t trust the Masters. I trust their self-interest. They’re trustworthy if they’re convinced that working with me is in their self-interest.

question: You don’t know them. You don’t understand them. We are not human in their eyes. They look at me and see a weapon. They look at her and see a whore.
answer: They look at me and they see a misshapen little beast. Their contempt is their weakness. They’ll underestimate us every time and we will use that to our advantage.

question: For now is the best we get in our profession.
answer: It’s not enough.

question: Considering the city was on the brink of civil war, I’d say it’s a good start.
answer: It’s not enough for Meereen to have peace. They need to know Daenerys is responsible for it. The Sons of the Harpy have a good story. Resist the foreign invaders. Our queen has an even better story. Mother of Dragons, Breaker of Chains and...all that.

question: The people know who brought them freedom.
answer: Yes, but do they know who brought them security? Who brought about an end to the violence? We need someone the people trust, someone they know who cannot be bought or influenced.

question: Sounds like quite the hero. Where would we find him?
answer: Who said anything about “him”?

question: Daenerys Stormborn is the one who was promised. From the fire she was reborn to remake the world.
answer: Yes.

question: She has freed the slaves from their chains and crucified the Masters for their sins.
answer: She did indeed.

question: Her dragons are fire made flesh, a gift from the Lord of Light. But you heard all this before, haven’t you? On the Long Bridge of Volantis. The dragons will purify nonbelievers by the thousands, burning their sins and flesh away.
answer: Ideally we’d avoid purifying too many nonbelievers. The Mother of Dragons has followers of many different faiths.

question: You want your queen to be worshipped and obeyed. And while she’s gone, you want her advisors to be worshipped and obeyed.
answer: I’d settle for obeyed.

question: I will summon my most eloquent priests. They will spread the word. Daenerys has been sent to lead the people against the darkness in this war and in the great war still to come.
answer: That sounds most excellent --

question: A man named Stannis Baratheon was anointed as the chosen one by one of your priestesses. He, too, had a glorious destiny. He attacked King’s Landing and was soundly defeated by the man standing beside me. Last I had heard, he’d been defeated again, this time at Winterfell and this time for good.
answer: We’d be most grateful for any support you could provide the queen.

question: And you, an honest servant of the lord, why should I trust you to know any more than the priestess who counseled Stannis?
answer: My friend has a healthy skepticism of religion, but we are all loyal supporters of the queen.

question: Would you?
answer: Look around. The city has come back to life.

question: You made a pact with fanatics.
answer: I did and it worked.

question: If you shaved your beard with a straight razor, you’d say the razor worked. That doesn’t mean it won’t cut your throat.
answer: Spoken like a man who has never had to shave.

question: I know.
answer: I hope you’re right about this expedition of yours.

question: You seem happy.
answer: I am happy. You should both be as well. Not so long ago, this city was ready to devour itself.

question: I will be happy when our queen returns.
answer: Why don’t you drink? Why don’t either of you ever drink?

question: Unsullied never drink.
answer: Why not?

question: Rules.
answer: And who made these rules? Your former masters?

question: I have tried wine before. It made me feel funny.
answer: That’s how you know it’s working.

question: I do not know any jokes.
answer: Grey worm?

question: The Starks and the lannisters, i thought these were enemies.
answer: Yes.

question: A joke is like a story, Torgo Nudho. Not a true story, necessarily.
answer: A story that’s supposed to make you laugh, ideally. Not at the moment, perhaps.

question: I do.
answer: Tell a joke.

question: I am soldier all my life. You think I never hear joke?
answer: You lied to us.

question: More jokes.
answer: I once walked into a brothel with a honeycomb and a jackass. The madam says- -

question: That changes nothing.
answer: The Unsullied could mount a defense off the beachhead. If the slavers’ forces- -

question: No more talking from you. Your talking gave us this.
answer: And I have acknowledged that. I’m trying- -

question: You’re trying to tell me what the army should do. You do not know what the army should do.
answer: All right, what should the army do?

question: We’ll not go to the beach. If we go to the beach, the Masters will take the pyramid. The pyramid is the only place in the city we can defend. We stay here.
answer: And then?

question: The city is on the rise?
answer: Meereen is strong. Commerce has returned to the markets. The people are behind you.

question: Good. Shall we begin?
answer: Do we have a plan?

question: You don’t approve?
answer: You once told me you knew what your father was. Did you know his plans for King’s Landing when the Lannister armies were at his gates?

question: This is entirely different.
answer: You’re talking about destroying cities. It’s not entirely different. I’d like to suggest an alternate approach.

question: Once before, I offered you peace. If you had not been so arrogant, you could have returned to your homeland with a fleet of ships. Instead, you will flee Slaver’s Bay on foot like the beggar queen you are.
answer: We are here to discuss terms of surrender, not to trade insults.

question: Our queen insists that one of you must die as punishment for your crimes.
answer: It always seems a bit abstract, doesn’t it, other people dying?

question: It was a long time ago.
answer: It was. And how have things been going for you since then? Not so well, I gather. Can’t imagine you would have murdered the Stark boys if things had been going well.

question: And he paid for them.
answer: Doesn’t seem like it. He’s still alive. It was complicated for you, I’m sure, growing up at Winterfell. Never quite knowing who you were. But then, we all live complicated lives, don’t we?

question: I’m not fit to rule.
answer: We can agree upon that at least.

question: Will their ships be enough?
answer: With the former Masters’ fleet, possibly. Barely. There are more than 100 ships in the Iron Fleet.

question: He murdered our father and would have murdered us. He’ll murder you as soon as you have what he wants.
answer: The Seven Kingdoms.

question: Reasonable.
answer: What if everyone starts demanding their independence?

question: I always thought this would be a homecoming. It doesn't feel like home.
answer: We won't stay on Dragonstone for long.

question: If Viserys had three dragons and an army at his back, he'd have invaded King's Landing already.
answer: Conquering Westeros would be easy for you. But you're not here to be queen of the ashes.

question: So you took it upon yourself to find a better one.
answer: Your Grace, when I was ready to drink myself into a small coffin, Lord Varys told me about a queen in the east who--

question: To keep yourself alive.
answer: Lord Varys has proven himself a loyal servant.

question: Your Grace, forgive me, but your translation is not quite accurate. That noun has no gender in High Valyrian, so the proper translation for that prophecy would be the prince or princess who was promised will bring the dawn.
answer: Doesn't really roll off the tongue, does it?

question: Prophecies are dangerous things. I believe you have a role to play, as does another. The King in the North, Jon Snow.
answer: Jon Snow? Ned Stark's bastard?

question: You know him?
answer: I traveled with him to the Wall when he joined the Night's Watch.

question: Summon Jon Snow. Let him stand before you and tell you things that have happened to him, the things that he has seen with his own eyes.
answer: I can't speak to prophecies or visions in the flames, but I like Jon Snow and I trusted him, and I am an excellent judge of character.

question: If you want the Iron Throne, take it. We have an army, a fleet, and three dragons. We should hit King's Landing now. Hard. With everything we have. The city will fall within a day.
answer: If we turn the dragons loose, tens of thousands will die in the firestorms.

question: It's called war. You don't have the stomach for it, scurry back into hiding.
answer: I know how you wage war. We don't poison little girls here. Myrcella was innocent.

question: We will lay siege to the capital surrounding the city on all sides. Cersei will have the Iron Throne but no food for her army or the people.
answer: But we won't use Dothraki and Unsullied.

question: And I suppose we're providing the Westerosi?
answer: You are.

question: Unluckily for me.
answer: Missandei is the queen's most trusted advisor.

question: She is.
answer: Does she miss me terribly?

question: I didn't ask --
answer: Well, it was. It wasn't. Anyway, she's much smarter than she lets on.

question: She's starting to let on.
answer: Good. At some point I want to hear how a Knight's Watch recruit became King in the North.

question: As long as you tell me how a Lannister became Hand to Daenerys Targaryen.
answer: A long and bloody tale. To be honest, I was drunk for most of it.

question: My bannermen think I'm a fool for coming here.
answer: Of course they do. If I was your hand I would have advised against it. General rule of thumb, Stark men don't fare well when they travel south.

question: Forgive me --
answer: Your Grace, this is Ser Davos Seaworth.

question: No. Of course not. But still, an oath is an oath. In perpetuity means -- what does perpetuity mean, Lord Tyrion?
answer: Forever.

question: Not to defeat Cersei. You could storm King's Landing tomorrow and the city would fall. Hell, we almost took it and we didn't even have dragons.
answer: Almost.

question: You told me you liked this man.
answer: I do.

question: In the time since he's met me he's refused to call me queen, he's refused to bow and now he's calling me a child.
answer: I believe he's calling all of us children. Figure of speech.

question: The Army of the Dead is on the march.
answer: The Army of the Dead?

question: You don't know me well, My Lord, but do you think I am a liar or a madman?
answer: No, I don't think you're either of those things.

question: If we don't put asside our enmities and band together we will die. And then it doesn't matter whose skeleton sits on the Iron Throne.
answer: If it doesn't matter you might as well kneel.

question: There's no time for that. There's no time for any of this. While we stand here debating --
answer: It takes no time to bend the knee. Pledge your sword to her cause.

question: I'm a prisoner on this island.
answer: I wouldn't say you're a prisoner on this island. You're free to walk the castle, the beaches, to go wherever you want.

question: Except to my ship. They took my ship.
answer: I wouldn't say we took your ship.

question: I'm not playing word games with you. The dead are coming for us all.
answer: Why don't you figure out what to do about my missing fleet and murdered allies, and I'll figure out what to do about your walking dead men.

answer: What about my earlier proposal? They could rule together as king and queen.

question: She's too strong for him. She'd bend him to her will, as she already has.
answer: He could temper her worst impulses.

question: As you have? You're drinking quite a lot. A Targaryen father and a Stark mother. Jon's the one man alive who might actually be able to keep the North in the Seven Kingdoms.
answer: How many kings and queens have you served? Five? Six? I've lost count.

question: You've always known my reasons.
answer: At a certain point, you choose a person you believe in, and you fight for that person.

question: Even if you know it's a mistake?
answer: I believe in our queen. She'll make the right choice. With the help of her loyal advisers.

question: You know where my loyalty stands. You know I will never betray the realm.
answer: What is the realm? A vast continent, home to millions of people, most of whom don't care who sits on the Iron Throne.

question: Millions of people, many of whom will die if the wrong person sits on that throne. We don't know their names, but they're just as real as you and I. They deserve to live. They deserve food for their children. I will act in their interest, no matter the personal cost.
answer: So, what happens to her?

question: My lord.
answer: Queen Daenerys demands Cersei's unconditional surrender and the immediate release of Missandei of Naath.

question: Queen Cersei demands Daenerys's unconditional surrender. If she refuses, Missandei of Naath will die here and now.
answer: Qyburn, you're a rational man.

question: Or so I flatter myself, my lord.
answer: We have a chance here, perhaps our last chance, to avoid carnage.

question: Yes.
answer: Help me. I don't want to see this city burn. I don't want to hear the screams of children burning alive.

question: No, it is not a pleasant sound.
answer: I- I don't want to hear it. Help me save this city.

question: My lord, I am only a mouthpiece for our queen.
answer: Your queen.

question: Cersei is Queen of the Seven Kingdoms. You are her subject.
answer: Her reign is over. You understand this. Help her understand it.

question: Jon Snow.
answer: Varys.

question: He knows the truth about Jon.
answer: He does.

question: Because you told him. You learned from Sansa. And she learned from Jon, though I begged him not to tell her. As I said, he betrayed me.
answer: I'm glad Sansa told me. I am your Hand. I need to be aware of any threats you're facing.

question: And Varys?
answer: Your Master of Whisperers needs to be aware too.

question: (angrily) You spoke to him first. Without coming to me. Without asking my permission.
answer: It was a mistake.

question: Why do you think Sansa told you? What do you think she hoped to gain?
answer: She trusts me.

question: Yes, she trusts you. She trusted you to spread secrets that could destroy your own queen. And you did not let her down.
answer: If I have failed you, my queen, forgive me. Our intentions were good. We wanted what you want. A better world, all of us. Varys as much as anyone.

question: In Meereen, the slaves turned on the masters and liberated the city themselves the moment I arrived.
answer: They're afraid. Anyone who resists Cersei will see his family butchered. You can't expect them to be heroes. They're hostages.

question: They are. In a tyrant's grip. Whose fault is that? Mine?
answer: What does it matter whose fault it is? Thousands of children will die if the city burns.

question: Your sister knows how to use her enemies' weaknesses against them. That's what she thinks our mercy is - weakness.
answer: I beg you, my queen-

question: The rearguard should be here by daybreak.
answer: She wants to attack now.

question: We speak the common tongue.
answer: Ah. Good. I want to be alone with the prisoner. Get some rest. Tomorrow will be a long day.

question: We have orders to guard the prisoner.
answer: Ordered by whom? The queen herself?

question: No.
answer: Well, in that case, as Hand of the Queen, I outrank whomever gave your order. Probably by quite a lot.

question: Cersei once called me "the stupidest Lannister."
answer: And you're going back to her, to die with her.

question: You've underestimated her before.
answer: She's going to die. Unless you can convince her to change her course of action.

question: When have I ever been able to convince Cersei of anything?
answer: Try. If not for yourself, if not for her, then for every one of the million people in that city, innocent or otherwise.

question: To be honest, I never really cared much for them. Innocent or otherwise.
answer: You do care for one innocent. I know you do. And so does Cersei. She has a reason now.

question: The child is the reason she'll never give an inch. All the worst things she's ever done, she's done for her children. It's not impossible that she'll win.
answer: She won't. Her enemy's forces have been depleted, as she said they would be.

question: Two of the three dragons are dead. She's evened the odds.
answer: The city will fall tomorrow.

question: She has the Lannister army, she has the Golden Company-
answer: I defended the city last time it was attacked. I know it better than anyone. It will fall tomorrow.

question: Then I suppose I'll die tomorrow, if not before.
answer: Why?

question: Sail right past the Iron Fleet and into a new life? Sounds a lot less likely than Cersei winning this war-
answer: There won't be an Iron Fleet for much longer. Do it. If you don't, you'll never see Cersei again.

question: I'll try.
answer: I never thought I'd get to repay the favor. Remember, ring the bells and open the gates.

question: Your queen will execute you for this.
answer: If Daenerys can make it to the throne without wading through a river of blood, maybe she'll show mercy to the person who made that possible.

question: You would have.
answer: You were the only one who didn't treat me like a monster. You were all I had.

question: It's not safe. Let me send some men with you.
answer: I'm going alone.

question: You freed your brother. You committed treason.
answer: I freed my brother. And you slaughtered a city.

question: No.
answer: Ah... Well... thank you for coming to see me. Our queen doesn't keep prisoners for long. I suppose there's a crude kind of justice. I betrayed my closest friend and watched him burn. Now Varys's ashes can tell my ashes, "See, I told you." It just occurred to me. I'm talking to the only man alive who knows where I'm going.

question: (sighs)
answer: So is there life after death?

question: Not that I've seen.
answer: I should be thankful. Oblivion is the best I could hope for. I strangled my lover. I shot my own father with a crossbow. I betrayed my queen.

question: You didn't.
answer: I did. And I'd do it again, now that I've seen what I've seen. I chose my fate. The people of King's Landing did not.

question: I can't justify what happened. I won't try. But the war is over now.
answer: Is it? When you heard her talking to her soldiers, did she sound like someone who's done fighting?

question: And you've been by her side, counseling her. Until today.
answer: Until today. Varys was right. I was wrong. It was vanity to think I could guide her. Our queen's nature is fire and blood.

question: You think our house words are stamped on our bodies when we're born and that's who we are? Then I'd be fire and blood too. She's not her father, no more than you're Tywin Lannister.
answer: My father was an evil man. My sister was an evil woman. Pile up all the bodies of all the people they ever killed, there still won't be half as many as our beautiful queen slaughtered in a single day.

question: Cersei left her no choice.
answer: The moment the gates fell, the battle was over.

question: She saw her friend beheaded. She saw her dragon shot out of the sky.
answer: And she burned down a city for it.

question: Ah, it's easy to judge when you're standing far from the battlefield.
answer: Would you have done it?

question: What?
answer: You've been up there, on a dragon's back. You've had that power. Would you have burned the city down?

question: I don't know.
answer: (scoffs) Yes, you do. You won't say because you don't want to betray her but you know.

question: What's it matter what I'd do?
answer: It matters more than anything. When she murdered the slavers of Astapor, I'm sure no one but the slavers complained. After all, they were evil men.

question: (sighs)
answer: When she crucified hundreds of Meereenese nobles, who could argue? They were evil men. The Dothraki khals she burned alive? They would have done worse to her. Everywhere she goes, evil men die and we cheer her for it. And she grows more powerful and more sure that she is good and right. She believes her destiny is to build a better world for everyone. If you believed that if you truly believed it, wouldn't you kill whoever stood between you and paradise?

question: Maester Aemon said it a long time ago.
answer: Sometimes duty is the death of love. You are the shield that guards the realms of men. And you've always tried to do the right thing. No matter the cost, you've tried to protect people. Who is the greatest threat to the people now?

question: My sisters will be loyal to the throne.
answer: Why do you think Sansa told me the truth about you? Because she doesn't want Dany to be queen.

question: She doesn't get to choose.
answer: No. But you do. And you have to choose now.

question: You are not here to speak! Everyone has heard enough words from you.
answer: (nods) You're right. And no one's any better for it. But it's not for you to decide. Jon committed his crime here. His fate is for our king to decide. Or our queen.

question: We don't have a king or queen.
answer: You're the most powerful people in Westeros. Choose one.

question: (to TYRION) I suppose you want the crown.
answer: Me? The Imp?

question: Who, then?
answer: I've had nothing to do but think these past few weeks. About our bloody history. About the mistakes we've made.

question: Bran has no interest in ruling and he can't father children.
answer: Good. Sons of kings can be cruel and stupid, as you well know. His will never torment us. That is the wheel our queen wanted to break.

question: Lord Tyrion, you will be my Hand.
answer: N- No, Your Grace, I don't want it.

question: And I don't want to be king.
answer: I don't deserve it. I thought I was wise, but I wasn't. I thought I knew what was right, but I didn't. Choose Ser Davos. Choose anyone else.

question: There's still a Night's Watch?
answer: The world will always need a home for bastards and broken men.

question: (sighs)
answer: You shall take no wife, hold no lands, father no children. The Unsullied wanted your head of course, but Grey Worm has accepted the justice of a life sentence. Sansa and Arya wanted you freed, but they understand our new king needs to make peace. No one is very happy. Which means it's a good compromise, I suppose.

question: Was it right? What I did?
answer: What we did.

question: It doesn't feel right.
answer: Ask me again in ten years.

question: I don't expect we'll ever see each other again.
answer: I wouldn't be so sure. A few years as Hand of the King would make anyone want to piss off the edge of the world.

question: Oh, I wouldn't say that.
answer: Oh, he's kind to me. Never would've guessed.

question: He-
answer: He what? What does he say about me?

question: We appear to be missing a Master of Whisperers. And a Master of Laws. And a Master of War.
answer: Yes, Your Grace. Suitable prospects will be brought to you for an audience in the coming weeks.

question: Perhaps I can find him. Do carry on with the rest.
answer: As you wish, Your Grace.

question: In full, my lord Hand.
answer: Good. Time to start incurring a new one. We have hungry people to feed. Can we expect some assistance in this regard?

question: Indeed we can.
answer: Lord Davos, we have an armada to rebuild and ports to repair.

question: You Master of Grammar now too?
answer: Grandmaester, ahem, it is my theory, based on my years of work on the Casterly Rock sewers, that clean water leads to a healthier population.

question: The strong live and the weak don't.
answer: Find the best builders and set them to the task.

question: I think that's a very presumptuous statement.
answer: I once brought a jackass and a honeycomb into a brothel.
